page.title: 02ORIGINS OF CODICOTE/WELWYN
page.content: In pre-Roman times, in a forest clearing, lived Cedda or Cudda in his hut or cot. Over the years Cudda's Cot, or Codicote grew and by 1085 there was a village housing about 24 people, a manor and an estate owned by St.Albans. Welwyn, meaning "by willows", grew by the ford across the River Mimram, which enabled the Belgic settlers to travel between Wheathampstead and Braughing. Later the Romans used the ford on their route between St.Albans, and Colchester.(The remains of the bathing suite of a Roman villa have been preserved for all to see under the motorway at Welwyn.) By 1085 Welwyn had a population of about 200 and it continued to grow especially when the road through it became "The Great North Road".
